dataset.title: Dormancy and germination in seeds of the medical Asian tree species Phellodendron amurense var. wilsonii (Rutaceae)

abstract.para: The effects of alternating temperatures, cold stratification and gibberellic acid (GA3) on seed germination of Phellodendron amurense var. wilsonii were investigated. Incubation at 35/10℃ or stratification at 4℃prior to incubation of freshly harvested seeds significantly increased germination percentage from less than 5% to greater than 87%. Germination percentage was increased only slightly in intact seeds treated with up to 2000 ppm GA3. However, partial removal of the seed coat by mechanical scarfication plus GA3 resulted in a drastic increase in both germination percentage and rate. Storage in liquid nitrogen for one and seven months enhanced germination percentage and the beneficial action was due to cracking of the seed coat. Embryos excised from their enclosing tissues and embryos surrounded by endosperm germinated to a much higher percentage than intact seeds, indicating that the water-permeable seed coat plays a mechanical role in preventing radicle protrusion in nontreated intact seeds. Improved germination responses were obtained when the physiological dormant seeds of P. amurense var. wilsonii were pre-treated for 3 months of cold stratification, whilst GA3 treatments also promoted their germination.

section.title: seed collection and preparation
section.para: Mature black fruits of P. amurense var. wilsonii were harvested from Taiping Mountain (24°30’N, 121°29’E), Ilan County, northeastern Taiwan, at an elevation of 1600 m in September 2004. The fruits are very oily and aromatic. Fruits harvested from natural forests or plantations should be rapidly transported to the handling place to avoid decreases in viability of the seedlots due to high temperatures in the transport-containers (Chien personal observation). Each fruit contains 3~6 seeds (average 5), but some of them are empty. Fruits were macerated by hand in water, and the empty seeds were floated off and discarded. The clean sunken seeds were used for subsequent treatments. The black seed (4~6 mm long and 2~3 mm wide) consists of the seed coat and a large dicotyledonous embryo surrounded by a small amount endosperm (figure 1). The spatulate embryo (Martin, 1946) is fully developed with a mean (± SE) embryo length : seed length ratio of 0.83 ± 0.02 (n = 15), and it does not grow within the seed before the radicle emerges. Moisture content (MC) of seeds was determined with three replicates of 20 seeds and calculated on a fresh-weight basis after oven drying for 17 hours at 103°C (ISTA, 1999).

section.title: Imbibition
section.para: Each of 20 non-scarified and scarified (cut at the point away from embryonic axis) seeds were weighed individually to the nearest 0.1 mg at time 0 and after incubation at ambient laboratory temperature (~24°C) for 24 hours on Whatman no. 1 filter paper in Petri dishes moistened with distilled water. Percentage water uptake was calculated as follows:
where Ws = increase in seed mass, Wi = seed mass after imbibition and Wd = initial seed mass (Hidayati et al., 2000).

Embryos were excised from each of 30 imbibed seeds, and then three replications of 10 embryos were weighed to nearest 0.1 mg before and after drying them in an oven at 50°C for 24 hours. Percentage embryo moisture content was calculated from these data as described above for seeds.

section.title: Effect of stratification on germination
section.para: For warm followed by cold stratification, freshly harvested seeds were placed in polyethylene bags (0.04 mm in thickness) with moist sphagnum and sealed, and then they were warm-stratified for 2, 4, 6 and 8 weeks at an alternating temperature regime of 30/20°C with 12 hours of fluorescent light (80-100 μMol m-2 s-1; hereafter light) at the higher temperature. These warm-stratified seeds were then given 4, 8, 12, 16 or 20 weeks of cold moist stratification at 4°C. A cold stratification treatment without a warm treatment was also carried out on fresh seeds in moist sphagnum for 4, 8, 12, 16 and 20 weeks prior to the seeds being subjected to germination tests. Each stratification treatment consisted of three replications of 100 seeds each. Water content of the sphagnum in both warm and cold stratification treatments was about 400% of its dry mass.

Germination tests using fresh seeds were performed in germination chambers at constant 25°C and at 35/10, 30/20 and 25/15°C (12/12 hours) in light during the higher temperature. Germination tests of warm- followed by cold-stratified seeds or of cold-stratified seeds only were performed at 30/20°C, i.e. same temperature as that for warm stratification. Sphagnum served as the germination medium. Germination, i.e. radicle at least 5 mm long, was recorded weekly. Results were expressed as percentage germination after 12 weeks and as the mean germination time (MGT) in days. MGT is a measure of the rate (speed) of germination and of the sharpness of the germination peak:
where ni = number of seeds germinated in ti days from the beginning of the test and Gt = total number of germinated seeds at the end of the test (Naylor, 1981).

section.title: Effect of GA3 on germination
section.para: Fresh, intact seeds were treated with 0 (water control) and solutions of 100, 500, 1000 and 2000 ppm GA3 (as K-GA3) (95% purity, Sigma, St. Louis, MO, USA) for 24 hours at room temperature prior to germination. Each treatment consisted of three replicates of 100 seeds. Without washing them in water, the treated seeds were then mixed with moist sphagnum and incubated at constant 25°C and at 30/20 and 25/15°C in light. Number of germinated seeds was recorded weekly for 12 weeks. Results are expressed as percentage germination and as MGT in days.

Due to the ineffectiveness of GA3 on intact seeds, the seed coat of seeds stored dry at 4 °C for seven months was cut at a point away from the embryonic axis to remove a small piece of the coat, and then the seeds were treated with the same concentrations of GA3 as described above. Without washing them in water, the treated seeds were mixed with moist sphagnum and incubated at 30/20 °C. Seeds were monitored for germination at weekly intervals for four weeks. Results are expressed as percentage germination and as MGT in days.

section.title: Effect of seed storage at 4°C and at subzero temperatures on germination
section.para: Seeds were air-dried to a moisture content of 8.8% and then sealed in aluminium foil packets for storage at 4, -80 and -196°C (liquid nitrogen, LN). Dried seeds in the aluminium foil packets were immersed directly into LN for storage. Each storage treatment consisted of three replications of 50 seeds each. At intervals of 1, 3 and 7 months, seeds were removed from storage and tested for germination. Seeds stored in LN were first placed at -20°C for at least four hours and then at 4°C for several hours prior to incubation. Germination tests were performed at 30/20°C in light, and number of seeds germinated was monitored at weekly intervals for six weeks. Results are expressed as percentage germination.

section.title: Effect of seed tissues cnclosing the embryo on radicle growth/emergence
section.para: Seeds that had been stored at 4, -80 and -196°C for seven months were sterilized for one minute in 70% ethanol followed by 10 minutes in 5% sodium hypochloride, and then they were rinsed five times with sterile distilled water. Different seed tissues were removed to assess their role in germination, i.e. the seed coat only was removed or both seed coat and endosperm were removed. The treated tissues were then placed in Petri dishes containing 20 mL of solidified MS basal medium (Murashige and Skoog, 1962) and incubated at 25°C for the germination test. Each treatment consisted of 20 seeds, i.e. each of four Petri dishes containing five seeds. Germination was monitored every two days for 12 days.

section.title: statistical analysis
section.para: Radical protrusion data were transformed to percentages based on number of treated seeds. Germination (mean ± SE) was calculated, and means were compared by analysis of variance (ANOVA) and by least significant difference (LSD) at the 5% level of significance (SAS, 2004).
